awd_titl_txt: Revealing Evolution of Electrons and Magnetic Field in Solar Flares
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern solar physics explores the Sun through new observations with fantastically improved spectral coverage and spatial, spectral, and temporal resolutions relative to only a few years ago, brought about by recent advances in technology.  In parallel, the complexity and volume of the data have been increasing proportionally.  The main goal of this three-year project is to tightly couple these multi-dimensional observations with theory, analysis tools, and modeling to obtain new knowledge and make fundamental scientific discoveries in solar physics, particularly about the nature of the physical drivers of the solar activity.   The solar activity depends critically on coronal magnetism, which, broadly speaking, includes magnetic field generation, control of morphology/topology, temporal evolution, and transformation into kinetic, thermal, and non-thermal energies in the Sun's corona, as well as coupling between the magnetic and thermal structures.  The ability to measure the coronal magnetic field and its changes on dynamic time scales is critically needed to uncover fundamental physics driving solar flares, eruptions, and activity.  While reliable direct measurement of coronal magnetic fields has been lacking, this project aims to radically change the situation by taking full advantage of the large wealth of high resolution data and modeling that is finally becoming available.  Specifically, a practical opportunity for routine use of radio observations of the Sun's corona for probing the magnetic structures involved in solar flares has recently become available for the first time from the new, fully functional microwave interferometer -- the NJIT's Expanded Owens Valley Solar Array (EOVSA) -- which has started regular interferometric observations of the Sun.  To make sense of these highly demanding data, with progressively increasing volume and complexity, and to integrate these data into a full synthetic picture of the magnetic and thermal structure along with accelerated non-thermal electrons in solar flares, this project will utilize sophisticated models that combine the most advanced theories, computational codes, and simulation tools with the data.

This project includes broad dissemination of the new knowledge gathered in solar radio-astronomy to enhance scientific understanding not only in solar physics, but also throughout astrophysics.  The fundamental nature of EOVSA's observations ensures a broad impact on the field of solar physics, including future instrument development for the DIKIST, FASR, etc.  The work will result in user-friendly software tools that will be made widely available to the solar and space weather community through the Solarsoft IDL distribution library.  These modeling tools will be used during the summer internships at the NJIT's Center for Solar-Terrestrial Research (CSTR), where the project team recruits local junior high school students to participate in cutting-edge solar research.  In addition, being performed within highly diverse environment provided by the CSTR at NJIT, the various project activities will advance discovery and understanding, while promoting teaching, training and learning.  In particular, the easy-to-use tools to be developed during this project make great learning tools that will be widely used in graduate courses at the CSTR, such as "Radio Astronomy," 
"Solar Physics," and "Plasma Physics and MHD."

The three-year project emphasizes the unique ability of EOVSA to quantify evolution of solar flares by dynamically measuring coronal magnetic fields along with the thermal and non-thermal electron distributions with high spatial and temporal resolution.  The project objectives include: (i) obtain evolving maps of coronal magnetic field and electron distributions in the flaring loops; (ii) build consistent evolving three-dimensional models of solar flares that, through forward fitting, simultaneously fit all available data, including the magnetic field, radio, X-ray, EUV and others; and, (iii) provide open access to these product to the scientists and the public.  The project team will adopt an integrated research approach that brings together new microwave imaging data available from the EOVSA, data from other ground-based instruments as opportunities allow, and data from the latest space missions, coupled with advanced modeling and forward-fitting, to obtain the three-dimensional magnetic field and particle distributions in flaring loops.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to understand and quantify the dynamic three-dimensional (3D) evolution of the magnetic field, accelerated electron distribution, and thermal structure of the flaring loops based on multi-wavelength observations and realistic time-dependent 3D modeling. A solar flare results from dissipation and transformation of magnetic free energy in the corona, although quantitative measurement of the magnetic field there on short flare time scales has not been previously available. With the availability of EOVSA radio imaging spectroscopy, we added the direct measurement of the magnetic fields in flaring loops to the data pool, which is critically needed to address the project objectives. For the first time, a very fast time decay of the coronal magnetic field was detected in a flare cusp region (famous 2017-Sep-10 flare). This discovery is reported in Science magazine (Jan. 2020). We demonstrated that the released magnetic energy associated with the detected magnetic field decay is sufficient to power the solar flare including the discovered bulk acceleration of nonthermal electrons in the flare cusp region (Nature 2022). The project provided new knowledge on solar flares; new computer codes and simulation tools have been created. The project outcome is documented in 15 journal articles in scientific journals, and many conference contributions, which have garnered more than 200 citations.

Intellectual merit. Using a combination of multi-wavelength data from radio to gamma-ray we investigated dynamics and evolution of the coronal magnetic field, nonthermal electrons and ions in the largest flares of solar cycle 24 that occurred on 06, 09, and 10 September 2017. Evolution of the electrons and the magnetic field has been obtained from a new methodology of the model forward-fit applied to imaging spectroscopy data of solar flares observed with EOVSA, which yielded evolving maps of physical parameters in the solar flares including evolving maps of the coronal magnetic field. The accelerated ions and their spectral evolution were quantified with gamma-ray spectroscopy along with the high-energy relativistic electrons. We also quantified the shortest temporal scales of electron acceleration and implications of these short scales on the underlying acceleration mechanism. We estimated the energetics and distribution of the released free energy of the magnetic field between different flare components, including thermal energy and the energy of accelerated electrons and ions. We quantified electron acceleration and trapping in an M-class flare that occurred on 2017-Sep-09. Evolution of the electrons and the magnetic field has been obtained from the model forward-fit applied to imaging spectroscopy data of this solar flare observed with EOVSA, which yielded evolving maps of physical parameters in the solar flares in the context of measured coronal magnetic field. We discovered, resolved, and quantified an essential coronal subvolume of a solar flare, where literally all thermal electrons were accelerated to high nonthermal energies--exactly where the magnetic free energy were observed to be released. The modeling and analysis tools, GX Simulator, GSFIT, and GSFITVIEW were substantially upgraded.

Broader impacts. All project personnel has been trained in using the interactive tools 'GSFIT' and 'GSFITVIEW'. Tutorial for other potential users of these products were performed in several scientific meetings. Eighteen high school students have been trained in using our modeling tool, GX Simulator. Fifteen research papers were published. Many seminar and conference presentations have been performed or scheduled. Numerous press-releases and media coverages highlighted our activities; in particular, the discovery of the decay of the coronal magnetic field in flares in 2020 and the discovery of bulk electron acceleration in the cusp region in 2022. Several interviews were published by popular science resources. The measurements of evolving coronal magnetic field and nonthermal particle evolution can serve as proxies for other eruptive phenomena in other astrophysical environments. Our modeling tools are being used for in-class demonstrations. Our new 3D modeling, visualization, and analysis tools have a great level of generality, while are very simple in the use, having high level of interaction and great flexibility in setting up the geometry and plasma properties. These are highly helpful in the presentation and teaching along with the research in the solar physics. They represent the most general, flexible, and convenient modeling tools developed so far and freely available for the community. The tools are already widely used for immediate teaching goals in the Center.
